So it was like terrible. i remember my hoodie still smelled like her and I wouldn't wear it cuz I didn't want the smell to fade. I gave up on everything. I bought a bunch of weed and carts and just let myself go. I would show up blazed off my mind to school. And I would see her sometimes and I was always wondering why. I was so out of it one time that I could barely see i was sitting at a bench and I see someone walking by in the distance and im like dammmn who’s that she just looks so different and confident. My friends were just staring at me like “bru thats mani” And I was just not feeling anything. I still feel like that but im trying not to let it get to me Ive stopped smoking for awhile now and Im trying to just talk to new people but in the back of my head she’s always their and I know as soon as quarantine is over and I see her again im just going to be right back at square one. listening to my music tuning out everyone just trying to get by. Peace _Luis

1. You talk about things you'll do together in the future, without realizing you're talking about the future. It's not weird to talk about that concert that's in three months or the trip you want to take to the beach this summer around him, because he'll be around to go with you. 2. When you say, "I miss you," it's because you really do miss him after only a day apart. It's not just a cute thing to say, it's a real ache that says he's a part of your life now. 3. You can't remember the last time you thought about your ex. Things with your guy now are so good you can't be bothered with whatever's in the past. 4. Things you usually hate seem OK — and even fun — if you're doing them with him. Riding a roller coaster you're terrified of? Fine, as long as he holds your hand and promises not to laugh at how you scream. 5. You're comfortable with making little sacrifices for him. You wouldn't put off your responsibilities for him, but if he's sick and needs you to help take care of him instead of going to brunch one morning, you're totally cool with that. 6. He's the "something good" you think about when everything else is really rough. Work is driving you crazy, but at least you've got him to cheer you up when you get home. 7. You feel safe when you're around him. It's hard to describe this feeling, but it really is the best thing in the world. Like nothing bad can happen. 8. You're comfortable enough around him to make bad jokes and be your fully weird self. You might've been trying to impress him before, but now you're cool to hum around the kitchen and wear your pants tucked into your socks when he comes over. 9. You keep seeing things out in public that you know he'd love. Stuff you used to walk by every day suddenly has David's name all over it. 10. He's your person. When something really good or really bad happens, he's who you go to first. 11. You're not worried about "scaring him off." You're comfortable enough to cry in front of him or show him huge, slightly embarrassing collection of Beanie Babies (that you swear could be worth a fortune one day), because you feel secure that he's not going anywhere at the drop of a hat. 12. Little things, like going to the grocery store, are better when he's around. A walk down the cereal aisle can be a very romantic date if you're with the right person. 13. He annoys the hell out of you, but you still want to be around him. "I love you, but I don't like you right now," is something you're almost ready to say. 14. You don't freak out if he doesn't text back right away. All that "does he like me back" anxiety is gone, and you finally have enough chill to be OK with his slow texting. 15. When he's sad, you're genuinely sad too. You feel his pain and he feels yours. 16. You're actually entertained by his cute AF childhood photos. And you actually like listening to his long, rambly stories. Just hanging out and talking about anything is fun. 17. You'd rather stay in and do nothing with him than go out. "Started staying in and going out less" is your new mantra, and it's totally OK with you. 18. You want to show him all of your favorite things. Not because you want them to be his favorite things too, but because you want him to know you better than anyone else. 19. You have to restrain yourself from talking about him with your friends all the time. If you could you'd gush about this guy constantly. But out of respect for your friends and their sanity, you hold back (a little). 20. You've started thinking about introducing him to your family. Because you genuinely want to know how he fits in around them. 21. You regularly catch yourself doing deep dives of his Instagram. And the best part is you aren't even scared of accidentally liking a photo, because you're past the point of feeling like you'll freak him TF out if you do. 22. You want to do things you've already done again so he can be there with you this time. Time to take a return trip to the Grand Canyon so you can kiss while the sun goes down and not care how cute or gross you look — you're in love, dammit! And you don't care who knows.

There is one person out there who has the ability to make you feel some emotions you have never experienced before with anyone else. Love cannot be just a perfect road without any flaws—but the day you cross the path of a specific someone, you feel like it's a no-brainer. You feel like it because of the effect they have on you. 1. Haaaappiness & Tiramisu That person makes you feel a bunch of pleasant feelings. They make you feel like you don't have to worry about anything, and it feels good. You are just peaceful and comfortable when they stand next to you. They make you laugh, and somehow, they make you feel blessed. Blessed because you know deep, deep down, you are the lucky one who gets the chance to bond a unique relationship with them simply because they agreed on letting you in on their world.  2. A story with Super Heroes That someone is neither Captain America nor Captain Marvel—and they are perfectly aware of that—but you can’t help feeling safe with them. On top of that, you feel comfortable in your relationship and your trust it. 3. No questions asked You are not scared of thinking about the future and including them in it. You don't wonder if that person will still be close to you in months and years because you peacefully feel like you don't need to wonder. 4. Cui-cui-cui, les oiseaux chantent (=birds are singing) You think of that person as being special because not only do they make you feel special, but they are, in reality, exceptional (most of the time.) You appreciate that someone for who they are. They have flaws, of course, like anybody else, but your thought about that is nothing else than: ––– (I let you complete that part.)  5. Dys-Dys-Dysfonctionality When thinking of that person, your brain doesn't function the same way. Your mind experiences an unlimited number of ideas and dreams, your words are meaningful, your feelings are intense, your adoration has no limits, your sweetness is pure, your honesty is genuine (and you might have the feeling you lost some neurons.) You do feel confident about being yourself, and you feel at ease with that person. 6. Extreme curiosity You observe that someone. You may stop doing whatever you are doing at a specific moment just to look at them, and you do not get tired of doing it because you simply adore that human being you are looking at—you just don't do it in a creepy way. What others think of you? You don't care that much, but you definitely pay attention to the way that particular person can see you.  7. Confidence pour confidence You trust them. You may not be able to give a reason for that, so, how come? Simply because your gut tells you so, and it is never wrong (or rarely at very least.) You don't have time to be angry toward that person. Do not get me wrong here; I am not saying you never pick a fight, you are mad sometimes, of course—you are a human being after all—but it does not last more than a few minutes–or a few hours if you are really, really, mad (but in that case, calm down, think clearly and open up the topic. Your anger will vanish.) 8. Et ça continue encore et encore (=And it keeps going over and over again) You love, you genuinely love, and you never stop. You are here and there for the others, but most importantly, you are here and there for that person. You care for any relationships you have with anyone close to you, but the one you share with that person is one of your favorite ones.  9. The reality of that game You don't need to play any mind games, be dishonest about your feelings, try any kind of manipulation or try to have any kind of freaking control. Everything sounds all natural. And if not, better to reconsider what you are doing. "What if" doesn't exist with that someone–or if you come up to use it sometimes, it doesn't last because you fight for what you deeply wish with them and you dare to live new adventures. You are aware that life is short and you know you don't want to waste your relationship with them. However, you don't rush anything either. You try your best to make sure both of you feel at ease and happy together, even if you know you are two independent people in the first place. 10. Click-click-click-click That particular person does not need to try being a light, that is just who they are, and you see them this way. As a matter of fact, you would better be with someone you feel happy to spend time with and who has the ability to blow your mind... in a positive way, of course-but anyone do whatever they want.  Anyway, yes, you love that person to the point that you try to think before saying anything hurtful, or painful, or regretful (OK, mostly – you are human after all.) But you keep in mind that you should not take anything for granted, especially not that particular person. Bazinga,

Knowing you're in love feels different for everyone. Some have been in love often and know the feeling well, and others may be not so sure if it's love or just a deep infatuation. Luckily, your body has some pretty sneaky ways of tipping you off to whether these feelings for your partner are more than just a passing phase. Keep an eye out for these tell-tale signs the next time you catch yourself wondering if you're actually in love. …. You can't stop staring at them… If your partner has ever caught you staring at them lovingly, it could be a sign that you're head over heels. Eye contact means that you're fixated on something, so if you find that your eyes are fixed on your partner, you may just be falling in love .Studies have also found that couples who lock eyes report feeling a stronger romantic connection than those who don't. It goes the other way too: when a study had strangers lock eyes for minutes at a time, they reported romantic feeling towards each other….. You feel like you're high__ It's completely normal to feel out of your mind when falling for someone. A study from the Kinsey Institute found that the brain of a person falling in love looks the same as the brain of a person who has taken cocaine. You can thank dopamine, which is released in both instances, for that feeling. This is a good explanation for why people in new relationships can act absolutely nonsensically…. You always think about them If you love someone, you may feel like you can't get them off of your mind. That's because your brain releases phenylethylamine, aka the “love drug” when you fall in love with someone. This hormone creates the feeling of infatuation with your partner. You may be familiar with the feeling because phenylethylamine is also found in chocolate, which may explain why you can't stop after just one square… You want them to be happy Love is an equal partnership, but you'll find someone's happiness becomes really important to you when you're falling for them. So-called “compassionate love” can be one of the biggest signs of a healthy relationship, according to research. This means that you're willing to go out of your way to make your partner's life easier and happier. If you find yourself going out of your way to keep your partner dry when walking in the rain or making them breakfast on a busy weekday morning, it's a sign you've got it bad.. You don't feel pain as strongly… Falling for someone might be painful, but if you've noticed that literally falling doesn't bother you as much anymore, it could be a big sign you're in love. A study conducted by the Stanford University School of Medicine had participants stare at a photo of someone they loved and found that act could reduce moderate pain by up to 40%, and reduced severe pain by up to 15%. So if you're getting a tattoo, you may want to keep a photo of your partner handy. Just in case. You're trying new things.. Everyone wants to impress their date in the beginning of their relationships, but if you find yourself consistently trying new things that your partner enjoys, you may have been bitten by the love bug. In fact, a study found that people who have claimed to be in love often had varied interest and personality traits after those relationships. So even if you hate that square-dancing class you're going to with your partner, it could have a positive effect on your personality. Your heart rate synchronizes with theirs… Your heart may skip a beat when you think about the one you love, but a study showed that you may also be beating in time with each other. A study conducted by the University of California, Davis, suggests that couples' hearts begin to beat at the same rate when they fall in love. Although you may not be able to tell if this has happened without a few stethoscopes, feeling a deep connection to your partner is a good a sign as any that you're in love. You're OK with the gross stuff.. If you're a notorious germaphobe and totally cool kissing your partner after just watching them pick their nose, you might just be in love. In fact, a study by the University of Groningen in the Netherlands found that feelings of sexual arousal can override feelings of being grossed out. So that means if you're super attracted to your partner, you may just let them double dip. That's love, baby.;) You get sweatier.. If you're nauseous and sweaty, you either have a bad stomach bug or are falling in love. A study found that falling in love can cause you to feel sick and display physical symptoms similar to that of anxiety or stress, like sweat. Although this feeling will probably pass once you really get comfortable with your partner, it may be a good idea to carry around an extra hanky, just to be safe. You love their quirks​.. If you really get to know a person, chances are you'll pick on the little things that make them uniquely them. And if you're in love with them, these are probably some of the things that attract you most about them. A study found that small quirks can actually make a person fall deeper in love with someone rather than just physical attributes because people have unique preferences. So although you may have judged your partner a little harshly on first glance, if you find that you're suddenly in awe of their uniqueness, you might be in love✿)

Obviously, as with any guy, it starts with physical appearance. I notice you as an attractive being and decide I want to meet you. As far as physical features, don’t assume the worst ladies, as many internet posts have said and many real people, generally it’s the face and especially eyes that I notice, but really any face. Then it’s the smile and or laugh. From that point forward it’s about personality. I think that what can get me often times is the shock that my assumption of what they are like. For instance, I met a girl that by anyone’s standards was drop dead gorgeous, so I assumed, not just based on this but other things to, that she might be a “mean girl.” But when I met her, I was completely caught off guard by her genuine humbleness and authenticity towards me and everybody. So side note for traits, I like humble attitudes and a genuine personality. The next thing I look for, partly because I’m not a talker, is someone who can carry on a conversation. But even more than that, I look for someone who I can connect to. I am not a person who just likes talking about sports and girls all day, I need a conversation that has sustenance of sorts, something deep or beneficial. Part of this is looking at similar interests of course, but just feeling like this is someone you could get to know is great. Beyond getting caught by surprise, I like girls who are straight forward, secure in who they are, can handle criticism, has emotional intelligence, tells me when I’m wrong, likes making plans (more of a preference because I don’t like to make plans), has similar interests that are mutually beneficial such as physical health or instruments, is encouraging… I feel like the list is getting long so I won’t go on, but I could. So when girls exhibit these traits and we connect on a personal level, I begin to feel like I’m falling in love. But usually it isn’t as we are talking, I’ll generally be at home reliving the day and then say, “ wow, I really enjoyed ____, I would like doing that again” and as I continue to lay there I can’t get them out of my head, sometimes even a week later it’ll hit me. The moment I realize I can’t stop thinking about a certain girl is when I decide I’m in love. But honestly the more I type this the more I feel like it is just my personal choice of when I decide to be in love, not something I can’t help but feel, so when I decide to is when i feel I’m falling in love.

Falling in love is such a pleasurable thing, the tell-tale signs are not easily missed because they take over your life for as long as the feeling lasts. They permeate every activity, they define one's actions and appear to take on a vibrant life of their own. There is no greater feeling than being in love, because that is strongly connected to one's feeling of self worth and acceptance, which makes it one of the happiest moment's of a person's life. The most obvious signs of love in the air are most evident in seven major areas of behaviour, especially the fist three: 1. Constant Loving Thoughts When we are in love, we cannot stop thinking about that person. We spend a lot of time imagining what we did with them (like that first kiss, or the way we met) and that is relived over and over; fantasising about spending time with them, and constantly wondering what they are doing while smiling to ourselves like Cheshire cats who got the cream! It is really difficult not to think about the loved one mainly because they make us feel happy; they make us want to shout out loudly from the rooftops, to tell the world how we feel, and they give us a quiet sense of satisfaction and self reinforcement in being loved, desired and wanted. 2. Increased Communication and Interest This is a time when the desire to communicate with the loved one is strongest. We tend to become more expressive and open. There will be lots of phone calls, visits and/or texts/emails between the parties. There will be dialogue around the most insignificant things. There will also be playfulness, teasing, expressions of endearment, tons of questions, and plans about the future, especially regarding sharing activities. In fact, it will be non-stop communication around the things that matter, coupled with an insatiable mutual interest in the lives of both parties. Everything, no matter how trivial, will assume importance and significance to maintain that connection and dialogue. This is because the very act of communicating is both enjoyable and self-reinforcing so both parties try to get even more of it. 3. Desire to Please Love gives us a strong desire to please. At such times we would go to the ends of the earth for the person we love. Nothing seems too difficult or challenging because we are trying to impress, to be given the seal of approval. In fact, we would even take up hobbies we do not like, if the other person is doing them, just to show how much we care about them and to gain their approval! When we love someone we want to make them notice us and to keep that loving feeling going as long as possible. This is where we are at our most compliant and amenable. It also explains why many people can be taken advantage of during these heady, vulnerable times. The most definite sign o falling in love is when that person begins to occupy your thoughts, even when you don't make any conscious effort to think about them. It is really about feeling good vibes towards her/him in a warm, comfortable way; a way you wouldn't feel about anyone else.

How can you tell that you are truly in love with someone? Simple answer, Sexual interest is not one of the first reasons you are pursuing that individual. There is a fine line when guys hook up with girls. Because they are sexually attracted the girl. (sole purpose of just wanting sex nothing more).They love her beauty and personality. ( present infatuation of the entire persons physical and personality traits. (In most cases 75% of the time her face is the most attractive feature to you, 25% is her personality, no other physical body feature bothers you or interests you aside from her facial beauty.I hope i am making sense. Let me try to rephrase myself, when you are truly in love with a person sex is the last thing on your mind, you are so in love that you almost do not want to have sex. (Let me continue explaining before you jump to conclusions.) To know that you are truly in love. When you constantly think about the person you love and how you are thinking of the steps to be in a partnership with themWhen you strive to become a better person and improve your physical and mental appearance solely for the person you are in love with. (becoming a better person).When everytime you see that person you choke up or become nauseous from anxiety.When you cannot sleep or focus because you are complelty focused on that person.Probably the most prominent give away that you are in love with them. When the persons beauty is so stunning that you cannot even remember what their face looks like, you can only see their beauty in person. Many of the crushes I have had in the past had a face I had a very difficult time recollecting mentally. Its funny because I would say to myself “I’m in love with that girl, but I dont even remember what she looks like”? Haha. I dont really know why this happens, the best logical answer I could give you is that when you see your crush you get stressed both mentally and physically, and somehow your memory blacks out for a moment. Another explanation could be that you dont want your crush to catch you looking at her. Your mind knows you shouldn't be looking at her but you want to, two conflicting pathways of the brain causes you to have a very poor image receptor I think.Its difficult to be yourself around them or you instantly feel self conscious when you see them. (elaboration) I want to give some advice to whoever has trouble with being themselves or becomes self concious either in public or around their crush. You have to realize that your best self is when you are being yourself. Think about it , try to remember when you are being yourself, were you with friends? family? co-workers? Do you remember how cool you were being? You talked with confidence, you were happy and outgoing, you were knowledgable, intellegent, and interactive as well as engaging. In other words, when you are yourself you are being “natural”. Your best self is being yourself, If you are trying to be someone youre not or faking your personality you are making it harder on yourself. People can tell when you are faking it ,and it exposes insecurity. It also makes friends and dates around you feel uncomforatble.STOP IT. I know its easier said than done but it takes time. Ever see average looking guy pick up a gorgeous woman? Most people think goldigger or something. In reality the guy just said FUCK IT IM GONNA BE MYSELF AND JUST TRY TO GET A GIRLFRIEND, I HAVE NOTHING TO LOSE, MAYBE I WILL GET LUCKY. They play by the simple laws of nature and win big. I know I said alot about looks and attraction, but a good quality original personality is just invaluable. Again being yourself means being “normal” mentally healthy. I consider myself a good looking guy, but my personality is unaturally quiet, introverted and serious due to my insecurities, My normal personality is laid back and outgoing without even trying (some people said I had way too much confidence when I was younger). in the beginning I had zero friends and little luck with dating due to this reserved nature of my personality, I started to not give a fuck and slowly open up to people. Now as for the sex part, if you are truly in love with someone you both take the initiative not even to mention sex until it happens naturally , not a one night stand, not a friends with benefit but only naturally by true love. There is a saying: You know you are deeply in love when you're not thinking about sex with the man. You will think about sex when you are in love, but first and foremost you know it from these signs. You know you are in love if you're sitting in a cafe and you know you only have a short time to tell him something sweet before you both leave (and you don't know if and when you you meet again), and you cannot yet tell him that you've in love with him. You know this moment will feed your memories for however long you'll be apart. So you're looking into his eyes, your eyes are locked and you say “hmm, your eyes are green" and you both have a chit chat about the colour of your eyes. You slightly ache inside, because you know this moment may never come again and you are silently saying “I love you.” You know you are in love, if you put on your headphones, because you mirror him (you know he loves music) and want to be close to him when you walk in the street without him. You're listening to the beats and the world around you blossoms as you walk, because he walks there with you, even though not physically. You know you are in love, when the love for him flows out of you, and through like a warm golden stream, whether you think of him or not (you mostly do) and goes out to every human being, animal, tree and flower, everything alive and all you touch. Real love transcends beyond the two of you. You know you are in love, when he smiles, his neglected yellow teeth show up, and you're strangely glad that they are part of him and you'd love to kiss them. Over and over. All other 'flaws' are so sweet to you, that you cherish them as the best parts of him, like a precious quartz stone with cracks ans scratches underlying the beauty of your stone you found in the most unlikely place. You know you are in love, when you feel electricity going through your body as the thoughts of you being intimate with him visit your mind. The chemistry is undeniable. You know you are in love, when you don't know when you might see him again, but you are not demanding and chasing. You let the love flow and be, for you know you can't separate yourself from it - it was your destiny to love without limits, expectations, unconditionally.

I used to wonder the same thing… until I fell in love at 29.  How do you know when a joke is funny or when something smells good? It’s intuitive. Laughter simply bounces out of your chest or you naturally go “hmmm” while tilting your nose up. It is the same way with love. One day you might be looking out of the window, running on the treadmill, shopping for groceries, holding his hand, you could be doing anything, and the thought simply comes, “I love him.” That’s how you know you're in love.  If you are unsure or question whether you love him, then you are not in love. Love exclaims itself proudly, leaving no room for doubt.  A related question is “How do you fall in love?” Many think love is a circumstantial happenstance that you have no control over. While fate does play a big role, my experience also tells me that you can as well. Here's my story: I grew up in a dysfunctional household. My parents had shouting-at-the-top-of-your-lung arguments daily. Dad cheated on Mom (among other heinous things). Mom told me never to get married. She said, "men are bad" and pointed to Dad as the prime example. Growing up, I didn’t believe in “true love.” I thought men cheated and lied and then you are stuck in a terrible marriage.  I was the poster child for emotional baggage. Although I met nice guys and got into relationships, I would inevitably turn them into villians (in my mind) and find reasons to breakup. I never let anyone through. I rationalized many reasons for this but the real one was that I was terrified I'd end up like Mom. This continued until I was 28. That year, I had a particularly heart-wrenching breakup. He was a great guy. A sweet gentlemen with a boyish innocence who adored me. I unconsciously played out my routine and pushed him away. Months passed. When I finally I realized what I had done, I broke down in full acknowledgement of how messed up I was. I just knew then that I HAD to change. My worst nightmare was living that way until I was 70 and dying alone, never having known love. I started a new journey to get to the bottom of my fears and create a new way of being.  I did my own version of "Eat, Pray, Love," going to meditation/yoga retreats, temples and ashrams. It was tough work clearing out my emotional junk but it was also exhilarating to get in touch with myself in a way I never had before and create new possibilities.  Within a year of my work, I met this incredible man and I fell in love. He is my best friend, my goofball, my sweetheart, and my trusted advisor rolled into one. Over the course of our relationship, I have learned to bring to him my raw and unfiltered self because I know that he accepts and loves every bit of me, from my sweetness to my crap. So coming back to the question, "How do you fall in love?" I believe that a part of it depends on you. I would not have the relationship I have today if it weren't for the work I did to clear out my fears and negative thinking about love.

Falling in love is one of the most exciting, rewarding and scariest things you could ever do. Once you’re in love with someone, it’s hard to remember how you lived without him or her. Of course, you were alive before you met this person, but you really didn’t start “living” until the two of you met. I remember when I first fell in love with my boyfriend; it was a very scary feeling, as I had managed to elude love for the entirety of my life before him. I specifically remember the transition from when I liked him to when I began to love him. He went from being someone who made me smile to being the greatest catalyst of the happiness and joy in my life. He went from a sexy guy I met to the most adorable person I know. He went from my crush to the love of my life. Everyone experiences love differently, and at different times. Even the meaning of love is extremely subjective, but I say for certain that anyone who’s experienced it knows it’s the best feeling ever. Here are 10 ways to know if you might be in love — rather than in like — with someone: 1. The best part of your day As Childish Gambino said, “When I’m alone, I’d rather be with you.” Seeing my boyfriend is always the highlight of my day. If you really love someone, you never truly get tired of him or her. No matter how great your day might be going, your special person will make it better. When you just like someone, he or she might make your day better, but probably isn’t the best part. 2. The first person you think about Your love will be the first person you think about when you wake up and the last person you think about before you go to sleep. When something good happens to you, this is the first person you want to tell. When something bad happens to you, you look to this person for support.  3. Prioritize above your own needs Love is selfless. I was the most important person in my world until I met my boyfriend. Once I fell in love with him, his needs became much more important than my own. This is just how love is. Your needs always seem trivial in comparison to your significant other’s needs 4. You’d do anything If I tried to construct a list of things I wouldn’t do for my boyfriend, the list would be pretty empty. When you’re in love with someone, you do whatever you can to make the person happy. When you like someone, you may feel like there is a lot you would do for the person, but you have your limits. True love knows no limits. 5. You are never afraid to express your feelings in public I have this semi-bad habit of telling the world how in love I am with my boyfriend. When you’re truly in love, you want everyone to know. You are not bashful about your feelings by any means. When you like someone, there is a lot of holding back on how you feel. 6. You love the imperfections My boyfriend is the most wonderful person I know, but he does have some imperfections. But, to me, they’re not imperfections — they’re unique qualities and things I love. When I tease him about them, he thinks I am making fun of him, but I am truly just admiring them. Love is the ability to know and accept someone’s faults. You may know the imperfections of a person you like, but having the capacity to embrace them likely won’t happen unless you fall in love. 7. You think long-term When you’re in love with someone, it’s hard to imagine a future without the person in it. For this reason, you will think long-term about how you can build a life with this person. You won’t give in to short-term temptations that might mess up your long-term goals. When you just like someone, thinking long-term can be pretty scary. 8. You become a better person No one is perfect; we all have room for improvement. But, being in love will force you to work on these things. You want to become the best version of yourself for the person you love. I am a better person now than I was before I met him. 9. Your feelings are unconditional When you love someone unconditionally, it means that your love knows no conditions and is absolute. I don’t actually like the term “unconditional love” because I think it’s redundant — I believe all true love is unconditional. When you like someone, your feelings change depending on the condition. 10. Your love is your best friend Sometime along the way, my boyfriend became my best friend. I believe this to be true for most people who fall in love. Your significant other becomes your partner in crime. You feel like, together, you can take on the world.

The feeling of love is complicated. Some people say you’ll just know when you are “in love,” but it can more complicated than that. Love is easy to both overthink and underthink. For one, the feeling of romantic love can be separated into separate types. The first is sexual, which is the feeling of physical attraction toward another person’s body and the desire to be intimate with that person. This is simple to gauge whether or not you feel sexually attracted to someone: either you feel it or you don’t, and this can change moment to moment. Second, is a flirtatious type of love where you enjoy their company, feel a sense of trust towards them, and find them fun to be playful with. This does not always lead to deeper love, but bridges the gap between non-romantic love, such as friendship, and deeper romantic love. The last two are the most important to understand: infatuation and committed. Infatuation is that obsessive feeling that you need to be with somebody. This is the feeling of living life through rose coloured glasses. Everything feels amazing when you are with this person and you can’t bear being away from them. Almost every one of their flaws doesn’t seem so bad and their good qualities make them seem like the greatest human of all time. Being with them feels easy. In contrast, committed love is not as obsessive and is more difficult. This type of love requires work and dedication to hold together. Committed love is that long-term feeling that a person truly matters to you, even through all of their flaws. You need them in your life. People confuse infatuation with committed love all the time, which can lead to major problems. Infatuation always fades. Some people call it the honeymoon phase. In movies and fairy tales, it’s the happily ever after stage: the prince gets the princess and they lived happily ever after. But in real life, happily ever after is never forever. For most, it lasts for about 3 months to 2 years. After that the real work begins. Committed love is different. It takes time and effort to build trust and value to bond together. It means not always being perfectly happy with your partner. It means sticking with them through tough times. Some people make the mistake of thinking they fell out of love with someone when the infatuation stage ended, but infatuation is just a trick the brain does to convince a person to invest enough energy into a relationship to bond to another person. Love is hard, but infatuation makes it feel so easy. When you are infatuated with another person: then you know. You can’t not think about them. But deeper romantic love is trickier. So, to the question “How do you know?”, well with infatuation you will just feel it burning inside and know, but deeper romantic love is trickier. Not everyone will go through the same level of intense infatuation: some aren’t wired that way and some people slowly begin to feel love towards someone over time. Just because a person doesn’t feel infatuated doesn’t mean that they don’t have romantic love for another. How long have you known this person? Is this somebody who you just really like spending time with or are they someone you feel you need to be around frequently. Do they have feelings towards you that are nearly the same? Do you legitimately care about their feelings and feel with them? Do you find yourself thinking before you act about how your actions will affect them? Do you want to be involved with their involvements? Do you feel willing to sacrifice your own needs for them? If your answer is yes to a lot of these, you might be feeling the early stages of romantic love. Or you might be feeling a weak sense of infatuation. My advice: don’t overthink it. Don’t read too deeply into it. I don’t know how old you are, but if you are young then just take it slow and see where it takes you. Be careful with infatuation: it makes people do stupid things. If you are still in middle or high school, then enjoy it but don’t overthink it. Your first love will probably not be your last, but that’s okay. Think of it as a trial run for the real thing later on. Some people think that teenage love isn’t real, that it’s only infatuation. There’s some truth there, in that most teenagers mistake infatuation for love, but love is still possible. It’s still developing and maturing. But it’s still real. Every relationship you have will teach you something about yourself and what you want in life. And if you still are unsure of what you feel then just go with the flow. Try things out. Just don’t make any significant life-altering decisions or let it ruin your friendships. One day you’ll have to make those decisions (probably in your mid-20s ), but you’ll have time until then. Figuring out love is a part of figuring out yourself. With time and practice, you’ll know more about what your feelings mean. I can’t tell you what you feel (especially from here), but I can advise you to just take it slow, go with the flow, and avoid making any drastic decisions (especially if you are in a state of infatuation). One day you’ll find someone who once the infatuation fades, and with significant time, is somebody who you’ll want to commit to. Maybe it’ll happen more than once. Until then, just enjoy the ride. Hope this helps.

So love is often misunderstood. First don’t worry too much about love itself and learn to enjoy what you have. But secondly, on to what we experience and how we define them: Attraction (platonic) - A simple friendship. Comfortable and enjoyable spending time with the personAttraction (erotic) - A more intimate form of friendship. Obviously there’s physical attraction in this case and what people call chemistry. Your body lights up like a lightbulb you feel a lot of things and it’s mostly physical. This is often mistaken for love - it isn’t.Like - The next level beyond any type of attraction is liking somebody. Willing to spend time with them for reasons other than physical attraction. Isn’t just limited to partners of course, but it’s important to have this with a potential partner you hope to build a future with. You don’t just like their looks, you like their mind. Their thoughts, their weirdness, their normalcy. You just genuinely like this person, and you’re not ignoring anything about them, you accept them for who they are and you like them.Love - Things get dark here, unfortunately. A great example of love isn’t from erotic relationships cause a lot more emotions will cloud what love really is. A great example is a parent - child relationship. A parent that loves their child might not receive it back. The child might in fact hate them, try to run away, say hurtful things and disregard their parent’s humanity and needs. But the parent loves them anyways. If you look at your partner, and know you’d stick by them, do right by them, even if they don’t - then you love them.It should also be noted that love isn’t a switch. There’s varying intensities of love:Weak love means you care about someone up until they piss you off and act hard headed. It’s like weak glue.A stronger love will see you survive some proper fights, grow together, and learn more about each other.The strongest type unfortunately can be so strong it hurts whoever owns that love. Some people stick by a person who has hurt them by cheating or disrespecting them. Some people love too easily and too strongly, and get easily manipulated and therefore hurt. It can get so bad that even suicide is considered because their heart has been broken and their love is too strong - that glue can’t let go. It hurts too much, and they want it over.In the end, love is something you nurture in your own mind, away from physical impulses and it’s unidirectional (your love may not ever be returned). My final piece of advice to you in general is to be willing to like everyone, but love only a few, and pick those you love very, very carefully. It’s worth the risk, if you pick the right person, but that doesn’t mean it won’t hurt.

You’re addicted to this person. Love changes the brain. In early-stage relationships, that euphoria that people feel appears as heightened neural activity in dopamine-rich areas of the brain—areas linked to the reward system—and in areas associated with the pursuit of rewards. There’s even some hint of activity in the anterior cingulate, the area of the brain linked to obsessive thinking, which is a classic experience when people are falling in love . As a relationship progresses into a long-term partnership, thinking about the partner activates the reward centers as well as brain areas implicated in attachment, but less so obsessive thinking.You really want your friends or family to like this person. New evidence shows that people are often motivated to “marshal support” for someone they are dating , which is consistent with the idea that the people in a person’s social circle often play an important role in the success of a relationship . Being attuned to how your family and friends might think about your partner or potential partner is a good sign that you are becoming increasingly attached to the person.You celebrate this person’s triumphs (even when you yourself fail). If you’ve fallen in love with someone, you probably have an atypical reaction when witnessing them excelling at something you don’t. Because romantic partners feel connected and can share the outcomes of each other’s successes, romantic partners will often feel pride and positive emotions when they see their partner succeed, even at something they themselves can’t do, rather than feeling negative and inferior.You definitely like this person, and this person likes you. Liking is different from love, but is often a prerequisite for falling in love. In a cross-cultural study, researchers showed that a critical factor recognized as directly preceding falling in love is reciprocal liking, when you both clearly like each other. In addition, an evaluation of the other person’s personality as highly desirable tends to be a precursor to falling in love.You really miss this person when you’re apart. In many ways, how much you miss a person reflects how interdependent your lives have become. If you are questioning whether you love someone, perhaps consider how much you miss him or her when you’re apart. how much people miss each other tends to correspond with how committed they feel to the relationship.Your sense of self has grown through knowing this person. When people fall in love, their whole sense of self changes. They take on new traits and characteristics, growing with diversity, In other words, the you before falling in love is different from the you after falling in love. Maybe you feel the difference, maybe others notice it, but the things you care about, your habits, how you spend you time—and or all of this is subject to the (hopefully positive) influence of a new romantic partner.You get jealous—but not suspicious. A certain amount of jealousy is actually healthy, not toxic. From an evolutionary perspective, jealousy is an adaptation that helps relationships stay intact by making its members sensitive to potential threats. People who are jealous tend to be more committed to relationships. Keep the jealousy in check, though: Reactive or emotional jealousy is the type that is predicted by positive relationship factors like dependency and trust—but people who engage in suspicious jealousy, which includes taking actions like secretly checking a partner's cellphone, tends to be associated with relational anxiety, low self-esteem, and chronic insecurity.Falling in love and building an attachment are a wonderful basis for a healthy relationship, but keep in mind that staying in a relationship (or, for that matter, choosing to start one) is often based on more than satisfaction and feeling good in another person’s presence. the staying power of relationships takes mutual investment and commitment. If love is passion, security, and emotional comfort, commitment is the necessary decision made within one’s cultural and social contexts to be with that person.

Everything is fantastic and nothing much annoying.When your smile gets wider and wider in every passing minute with him.When you don't need a reason to smile and a joke to laugh.When you are sweet as hell. As girls only remember someone's numbers when that person is too important. They don't give any unimportant person space in their memory land. Things that bother you, things you fear, deep secrets, and our bucket list.When you keep checking your phone. Your phone is now your oxygen cylinder. You can't even breath without looking at your phone.When reality is more beautiful than dreams. When his voice become lullaby in nights. Nothing better you can ask for.When his face keeps appearing in every person you look at and his thoughts keep running your mind all day.When you cherish day-dreaming and sleepless nights.When you crave his voice. And can hear him talking all night watching the moon in the sky.When you want to look gorgeous just for him.When the whole world vanishes before his dazzling eyes.When cute fights between you two start irritating your friends and no longer they want to give you two company.When he gave you a cute name and when he calls you by that name flowers started blooming in your stomach.When you ask the winds to tell him, how do you feel and how much you miss him.Suppose you have the power to be invisible for a hour, you can go anywhere and can do anything. If instead of going to to a mall or store and lifting clothes; you think of going to him and seeing how his face looks when he is sitting alone in the chair next to window texting you. How his cheeks got red and eyes to blush, that is all you want to see, then you are in Love.If you can imagine a life with him and ever thought how awesome your children are going to be then you are in love.You walk with a cloud with white face pink cheeks above your head which has a room for every memory of him, and you keep looking for a chance to disappear in that memory cloud.When you love hearing your name in his voice.When every person with the same name makes you smile.When you walk slowly with him so that path never ends.When words stop talking and silence is connecting hearts.When he becomes a part of your prayers.When you listen to his favourite song again and again, to know his side of the story.When a person can make you believe that heaven is on earth then, you are in Love.When you desire to have a kid who has a dimple on one cheek like him, all his tantrums is as cute as his. When you can see his presence- all of him, in every nook and corner of your life, then you are in Love.

You just know. There is no doubt at all — and no need to tick a checklist, or source opinions on Quora (although all questions are welcome and thank you for yours). ● Other person is always on your mind: first thing in the morning and last thing at night. ● Physical sensations of being truly alive and thriving and a peculiar sensation in the abdomen/solar plexus of a yearning/aching-warmth for the other person. ● You crave the other person's company: their touch/contact, their kiss, being able to see them, talk to them, listen to them, etc. And going home afterwards feels like you are ripping yourself away from them such that you already can't wait to see them again before you've even left. ● You see “into" them: beyond the superficial seeing that a stranger does. You see their quirks, charms, the good and the not so good, the whole of their personality and all that they are: and you still like (or love…) them for being exactly as they are. ● If you're young, it's all a rush and all-in head spin. When you've known love before, you enjoy a slower pace. Perhaps. People differ. These are just the obvious things that come to my mind — but for the absolute simplest truth: see the first sentence of my answer again… ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\ Addit: ● You start to factor the other person into your thoughts and decisions. ● You seem less interested in other “competing" parties. You desire exclusivity — to share all of yourself with the other person only, and you hope for reciprocity (unless you are one of these new-love jerks that's all about open relationships and non commitment etc — just my opinion that you jerks are jerks, so don't jump down my throat for saying it…. Ya bunch of JERKS lol!). Or perhaps another way of looking at it is you desire a relationship with that person where you both occupy special places in each others lives. ● You are happy to be vulnerable, take the armour off, take a risk, and hope for the best. ● Your friends and family will sense it in You… And unhappily accept that there's a new voice that carries influence in your life, and they better fall in line with the new world order because “so and so is amazing — don't say anything bad about so and do…”. MAYBE: This one also is a bit down to who you are inside yourself. ● Heaps more - maybe someone else can keep the list going? (…) ------------------------------ Addit thanks to Linda Mayes: You feel comfortable around them. All the things that reside in the old love story doesn’t matter. Netflix, laughs and a home cooked meal seems boring to everyone else but amazing to you. You start to create your own love story. The warmth and feeling you receive from them. When you feel the love, it’s is only right yet natural to give back. They appreciate every flaw you have. They always encourage you & want you to be your best. They always believe in you. They never bring you down and want you to be your best at everything you do! My favorite one: Consideration for one another !!! The most important trait. Love will truly go so far with this one. Sharing everything. Only the two of you knows what nobody else knows about one another & knowing that they are secure & it stays between the both of you only. Even when things go bad. Why? Because they are your best friend too!! Material, & other outside instances really don’t matter. Who doesn’t love them right? But if they are gone the love will still be there;) You get butterflies or your heart is beating out of your chest. When you feel & know for a fact that they love you; not by what they say, but what they do!! ● Anyone else care to add to the list?

Being in Love is that thing where you become vulnerable and give someone the ability to destroy you, but you trust them not to. Love is unconditional, selfless, it makes you happy when you see your soulmate happy, you feel better with her/him, you truly care for the other person, their appearance doesn't matter, perfection doesn't matter, you can love them for what they are and what you are when you are with them. Most of the time, we know we are in true love, not from the butterflies when she/he is around , but from the pain when she/he has gone away. Love need not always be mutual. Love comes from within. It doesn’t need to be reciprocated. We feel happy if it is, but if not, we will still continue to love the other person for love comes from within. A crush is short lived. Lust and strong physical attraction fade over time. The initial infatuation fades. It is just a strong sense of desire and attraction knowing only the superficial details about the other person. It makes you feel happy. It eventually fades with time. True love, on the other hand, takes time and lasts forever. It nurturers and it grows over time. It is real and it is a feeling where the other person's happiness is a priority over your own happiness. Love cares for the other person. Rejection from a crush hurts, but you will get over it with time. But rejection from the one you truly love, stings and kills you, because it takes away a part of you. True love is unconditional and selfless. You love someone because you want to, not because you will get something in return. That is what love is all about. Do you still love someone even though you know you can't be together? I’m sorry for strangling you with my true love. I’m sorry when I love you unconditionally even after you wanted me to stay away and move on. I’m sorry if my care appeared as pestering. I’m sorry if my love appeared as torture. I’m sorry if not moving on appeared as my weakness. I’m sorry if not letting you go, appeared as stubbornness. I’m sorry if I have ever made you fear by showing my vulnerability. I’m sorry if I have ever made you freak out by showing my endless love :’( I’m sorry if everything appeared to you as Whiny. I’m sorry if everyone misled you that I whined when I was probably trying to be understood. I’m sorry if my intentions of wanting to be understood appeared as clingy. I’m really sorry. It was all because I truly love you unconditionally. Even after you broke my heart a million times, those million pieces still love you to the truest of its senses. Because that is what love is all about. UNCONDITIONAL. But all I wanted to say to your deafening Silence when you cut me off from your life and left is that “Staying away and no communication is never a solution to anything in life my dear.” It is not that I didn’t accept that you don’t want me anymore in your life, but that I still love and care about you even though you can’t give me anything in return. It is not because I can’t move on or don’t want to move on, it is because my love for you is true. I am not crying because it ended. But because I still love you. Even after you ended it and ignored me completely. Tears start rolling down my cheeks, when I guide your hair behind your ears ,in the latest picture of yours.The moment when a picture speaks a thousand words. Every love story doesn't have a happy ending, because TRUE LOVE doesn't have an end. I still love you in silence.

I‘ll try my best to answer your question from the perspective of an old guy, but have to begin by pointing out that the words ‘romance’ and ‘romantic’ can be confusing Ignoring the literary definition of romance, which I vaguely recall referred to a story about a hero with a tragic flaw, romance seems to mean completely different things to different people. To many people, including most of the young people I know, it refers to a sexual relationship based on physical desire , but not necessarily a relationship expected to last very long or that is deeply felt. To others like myself, it connotes a deeper and more spiritual concern for another's well-being, and calls to mind a relationship where sex is an important but not crucial component. Fortunately, both of those concepts are easily distinguished from the love a person feels for their parents or other family members, which are not of a sexual nature at all. I'll take a huge leap of faith that you are referring to the deeper meaning of ‘romantic‘ which I subscribe to, since I hope you can tell when all the crazy chemicals in your body make you ‘want’ someone in a way you'd never think of with a family member. So - how do you know if you love someone versus being ‘simply’ attracted to them? The truth is, you can't always tell. Sorry, but we are all capable of lying to ourselves, and we do that most often when it comes to our feelings. When you find someone attractive, which is based on their appearance, your own experiences and ideals, and of course hormones, it's very easy to not notice or even ignore flaws or incompatibilities. Moving to another level, good sex - I know, I know, someone is already typing “it's all good” - can completely distort a person's rational thought processes. Things can become even more confusing if your love interest is very kind, or understanding, or displays some personality trait you crave for one reason or another. It's no surprise then that so many couples sincerely believe they're in love with each other and then are amazed to wake up one day and admit that they either don't really know, or don't really like their partner. But I don't mean to seem so gloomy, because there is one simple way to determine if you really love someone. You just make a decision. You think about the person, acknowledging all of their virtues and then honestly considering all of their faults, even those that are in actuality your problems, for instance if you're averse to pets but they love cats. You concentrate on the negatives, and ask yourself if you can live with those the rest you your life. Important point, which deserves a book in itself - don't count on ‘changing’ the other person's behavior, or opinion, or attitude. That could happen, but the only thing you can be sure of changing in how you feel about their behavior. Think long and hard about those things you dislike, and especially about moral values which you share or differ on. For instance, if I found out that the kindest, most generous, most beautiful woman I ever met felt that she was superior to people of another background or culture, I know that I could never enjoy spending time with her. I might be able to overlook any number of mannerisms or a stubborn streak or a tendency to argue about silly things, but not issues of character. Of course for some people, the things most aren't likely to notice can be deal breakers. On of my sisters wouldn't go out with a guy who even occasionally used the wrong tense, for example saying “she don't” instead of “she doesn't”. In her defense, our mother was Italian and insisted that we always use proper grammar, so it was very jarring to hear the way many people butcher the language. But my point is that every one of us has unique personal and often trivial preferences and if we choose not to change or eliminate them, we must be willing to have our choices reflect them. So you don't know if you love someone, you decide to love them. Love is not a feeling, nor an emotion, it's a decision. Feelings are basically hormones, or sometimes difficult to understand aspects of our own unique personal psychology resulting from upbringing and experiences. They are fleeting and sometimes surprising. Emotions are much the same but are more consistent and more apparent by our actions; still, they are nothing more than our outward reactions to specific events. If someone were to insult you, causing you to feel hurt and become angry, you would (hopefully) not kill them because of your hurt feelings and angry emotion. Yet we are all conditioned by modern culture to think that it's sensible for two people to marry and commit to a lifetime of togetherness because of feelings in their crotch (hormones) and the fact that they feel cared for when the other person compliments them (emotions). So, real and lasting love is not about feelings or emotions, it's a decision, cold as that may sound. You must look at yourself objectively and your potential partner critically, and then you decide. Do the things about the person that appeal to you mean enough that you would choose to accept those things about them that bother you? Conversely, are there aspects about that person that you find lacking as compared to your ‘ideal’ that are more than offset by less obvious characteristics that you never thought of looking for. One of my friends in college who was very petite, about 5′ tall weighing less than 100 pounds said she'd never even consider any guy over 5′-9″ because she felt they'd look odd together. But the last time I saw her she was dating a guy who was 6′-5″ because she said he was the first guy other than me who didn't treat her like a child and constantly make jokes about munchkins. Those things about a person that are simply unacceptable and those that are absolutely necessary in order for them to be considered at all are different for each of us, but that's fine, because we each have to decide what matters. But in the end, the most important thing to know is that you alone can choose what matters to you. Once you know that, whether or not you love someone is simply a choice you make. Some find that discouraging, as they are apparently enchanted by the mysterious twists and turns of fairy tales and Disney movies. But others of us find that realization to be the most empowering and powerful aspects of humanity - that we are not ruled by fate or chemicals, but that instead we have the power to choose.

She was waiting for me in the college, when she called. I picked up in the first ring. Her: Hey. Are you coming? Should I wait here? Me: I have almost reached. Give me some time. I have already reached the place long back. To be honest, I couldn’t sleep the whole night before in excitement. I kept looking at clock and her picture. She was beautiful but I was scared to face her. I was conscious this time. I never felt like that before. I pretend that I am looking for her repeatedly, when she called me. I looked behind and I felt numb. I couldn’t speak at that moment. She kept saying things, but I was lost in her. Her: Hey. Is something wrong? I am really nervous. I never stayed far away from my home before. I was concerned and worried. I wanted to make her comfortable. I wanted to hold her hand and hug her. I wanted to assure her that I am with her. I would never leave her at any instance. There was something wrong with me that moment, as I was talking to myself rather than answering her. We met again. This time, she was worried that her phone wasn’t working and she didn’t know our place quite well. I started to leave things in the middle and getting ready. I ran miles on foot to reach college. I couldn’t breathe even properly as I never did that before. I knew something wasn’t right but I started loving this change, which I wasn’t aware of. Me: Is everything alright? Give me your phone. I will do something. I never felt so confident before. I always needed extra preparation to feel that way. I didn’t know what I was doing. We ran into innumerable shops but couldn’t find the solution, when she felt sad. I couldn’t see her sad and I started doing something on her phone and it clicked. Problem is solved and she jumped out of excitement. She hugged me. I felt strange and I was speechless. It was something unimaginable for me that instance. I couldn’t sleep that night too. There was something seriously wrong with me now as I was trying to connect with her, when I missed her beautiful presence. This time, she was volunteering for blood camp but she didn’t call me specifically. I never did any voluntary work before, but I wanted to try this time. I called her and she felt happy. We met again. Supposedly, she was coordinating and I preferred to be her volunteer. I started following her ideas. She was good at leading this camp and everyone was impressed. Everyone started reaching out to her, but I kept working on my activity silently. I just visited that camp to spend time with her. But she didn’t know that I even existed. Later, I left the place without informing her. I didn’t sleep that day too. But this time the reason was unusual. I felt sad when we couldn’t spend time together. Next day, I preferred to stay away from her sign. I tried focussing on my studies as I was hurt. We never talked for a month. I was still dealing with my feelings. I felt I was too immature that instance. She called me on my birthday. I never told her about it. She repeatedly asked me to meet her at college. I made up some excuse and she felt sad. I hung up. But all this time, I even felt guilty. I knew the place where we used to hang out the most. I surprised her. She hugged me and wished me. I almost forgot all the pain. We shared good times together that day. This time, I wanted to do something special for her. Her: Hey. Chill. I will go on my own. Don’t worry. Me: No way. Its already late. I will drop you. Please I insist. Her: Okay great. We will have more time to spend together then. She was excited and I felt relieved. She kept talking all the way, and I kept listening to her. I dropped her at her hostel. It was awkward moment but this was new for me. I didn’t know what I am supposed to do. Me: Okay Take care. Thanks for your time today. She ran towards me. Her: Please call me when you reach your hostel. I will be waiting for your call. Don’t keep me waiting. She smiled. And I was speechless. I recall that I kept singing all the way during my journey back to my hostel. Now I know, I was in love definitely. After few days, I received a text, “Sorry. I couldn’t reply. I had some tests so I have to go to hospital”. I was silent. I couldn’t understand what she had been going through. I had to skip next class and so I ran to visit hospital. I was angry as well as worried. It kept bugging me, ”Is she okay? Why didn’t she tell me? It was my fault. I should have asked her. Why I couldn’t keep my ego aside? ”. I finally saw her. She smiled and I felt relieved. It was difficult for me to see her like that. This time, I couldn’t control and I hugged her myself. Her: Hey I am alright. Nothing happened. But I couldn’t believe her. I couldn’t sleep that day too because every now and then, she was affecting me. She was all over my mind, wherever I would go. At first, love feels like a serious affair but it is something that we aren’t aware of. Loving someone wasn’t all about spending beautiful moments together. It was all about how you feel, when you miss her beautiful presence every now and then. When you miss being with her, then you realise and wish you could have more time together and that is love. Loving someone takes a shear amount of quality time to understand your feelings but when you get there, you don’t want to leave that beautiful place again.

It’s very difficult to answer this question. It would be like explaining to you when your are hungry: no one better than you can tell. Citing a quote from Pierre Beaumarchais, though, can help you to understand when your feelings towards someone else are genuine: Where love is concerned, too much is not even enough. Imagine these two examples, inspired by and freely translated from an Italian book written by mental coach Giacomo Papasidero.[1] #1 It’s your birthday. You come back from work and discover that your partner has arranged a surprise birthday party for you and invited your best friends. You spend a wonderful evening with them and with the person you love who has arranged it just for you; then, when everybody is gone, there is still time for her to surprise you once more with a night of passion. In the morning you wake up and smell the coffee that she has prepared and brought to bed for you. What a wonderful person, the one you love. What you don’t know, though, is that she has a secret lover and that the day before, in the afternoon before you came back from work, she “celebrated” your birthday with him in your couch. #2 Now think of someone else. A couple. They are doing really well in the love department, until one day he decides to spy on her mobile and discovers a few messages from a common friend who had a flirt with her before the couple got together. He gets furious and accuses her to betray him. He starts being suspicious every time she goes out with her friends. She denies any wrong doing and tries to reassure him with hugs, attentions and sweetness any time she can; but he doesn’t believe her, he feels ripped off and thinks that those nice gestures of her are just fake. He feels that she doesn’t love him. But the truth is that she is really honest, she has never betrayed him or even thought to betray him and that the common friend is just…a friend.  Isn’t it bizarre that you, who are betrayed by your partner, feel like the luckiest person on earth, while the guy from the other couple, who is genuinely loved by his partner, feels betrayed, disappointed and unloved? We truly love when we are not concerned. The guy from the second couple doesn’t really love his partner. He loves (loved) her alignment to his expectations. When this comes less, concern kicks in and the truth, which would be evident if he was truly in love, becomes secondary and blurred. He is moved by personal gain, not by unconditional love. True love is not measured by how happy the other person makes you feel, but by your spontaneous desire to make your partner happy. Think it like this: would you feel loved by a friend who shows to be as such only when he can gain a favor from you? No, you are not loved by him. And yet, you probably keep doing him these favors he needs. Why? Because you truly love him. Because you don’t need to receive anything in exchange, when you truly love someone, not even love itself. Footnotes[1] Imparare a essere felici eBook: Giacomo Papasidero: Amazon.it: Libri

One starts to know they are falling in love by the feeling they get when they are with the person, the things they start doing for the person, they way they behave when they are with the person, the way their thoughts are filled when the person is away. One starts feeling butterflies in their stomach when beside that person.One starts giving attention to the person.One tries to make eye contact with the person but then feel shy.One starts feeling the attraction for the person.One wants to get noticed by the person.One starts dressing beautifully for the person.One tends to know the likes and dislikes of the person.One tends to get shy when they are around the person.One tends to think most of the time about the person.One tends to smile, laugh along with the person.One tends to start looking for the person.One tends to day dreaming and talk within themselves thinking about the person.One tends to feel like spending most of the time with the person.One tends to make excuses with family, friends to meet the person.The One wants time to go slowly when they are with the person.One starts listening to the love/romantic songs thinking about the person.One starts re-playing the best moments spent with the person.One starts buying gifts, dresses for the person and surprising them.One wants to know more details about the person.One wants to be the priority of the person when they want to share something.One tries not to be angry with the person.One starts doing little things for the person like cooking their favorite dish, collecting their fav songs etc.One starts waiting patiently for hours for sake of the person.One awaits for the compliments from the person and starts blushing when they hear it.One starts going out for movies, lunch, all the places in the town with the person.

Signs that you are in love? Like seriously? Ooh C’mon you beautiful creature, love is never so tangible and objective. Had it been so, the world would have been filled with resplendent stories which generally get lost in obscurity due to vague nature of love. There are no signs, rules, equations, algorithms… Just emotions and instincts. I remember a beautiful story here. Once Ross asked Joe, tell me how much love is emotional and how much of it is physical? To which Joe elegantly replied, “love is 99% physical and 99% emotional and the best part is, rules of mathematics do not apply here”. Still there are some pretty obvious cues that you are going into that tender phase of being in love. Some of them might sound silly though but again logics don't apply here:). When some part of you is always lost somewhere other that your physical location and your colleagues keep complaining of that. And high part is, you are completely okay with those complains and taunts. When you are into middle of something, however tedious, monotonous or messy it is, a sudden thought of a particular person comes and pours an elixir of joy in your mind and mood.You start smiling and others are like, what's wrong with him/her?:) You start observing changes in yourself. All the music and poetry which you cherished just as an avid reader now mean a lot to you. They seem highly relatable and relevant now. Your perception about life and people changes and you become more empathetic.  Things get really interesting if you have habbit of self talking [applicable to me :)You start enjoying your company more than anyone where you keep rehearsing all those honest emotions which you want to convey to that beautiful personality which has now become a part of you, which is always with you,obviously not literly but metaphorically. Things get really pathetic when you see that you haven't ever initiated a conversation with that person, this situation keeps killing you, believe me. It's not that you are afraid or insecure about intensity and honesty of your true emotions. It is just that you don't want to loose the treasure you already have[unexpressed, unrequited honest love]. Mere thought of losing a person you never had with you scares you to the core. This most beautiful yet cruel thing about being in love.  Stalking over social media and other such deeds are way to mainstream. You never start a conversation even there because again can't risk being stereotyped as another random highly infatuated creepy Romio. If your emotions are short lived and more tilted towards bodily pleasures and not with mind and personality of that person, them I am sorry pal, you ain't in love, you are just infatuated.  Infatuation is disorganised form of enery of your brain. But love of is same energy dancing elegantly on the choreography of your heart beats,highly pristine and resplendent. If you are just infatuated then you will get over this in 21 days or so.But being in Ishk[love] will never fade. It's just constant or keeps on increasing, each day with a new sensation in mind, with a new note in the beats of your heart. In the end…. Love is love, no metaphors,no explainations. Ved. |Evanesco|
