Let's first start with a description of love. There are several types of love; I assume you are referring to romantic (or eros) love. Love is an act of giving. True eros love is a deep and steadfast mutual DESIRE to GIVE of ourselves to each other. Therefore, it is crucially important to understand that love is not a duty or obligation of some sort; it is a shared passion. As a desire, love is steadfast and very persistent. It compels us to act. If we don't it “nags” at us. It draws attention to itself and demands response. This is because love has a gravitational pull, and it is very hard to resist. :) Love makes us feel good. Good about life, good about ourselves, good about our future. Love is GOOD and it literally produces good and “sweet” fruits. Love, sweet love. There is nothing bitter about it. There is also nothing fearful about it. Love overcomes fear. Finally, love begets love, so it stands to reason that authentic love makes us love ourselves more. This is why lovers often remark “I love myself when I'm around you” and “you bring out the best in me.” :) There are many great love songs with such titles. Love compels us to express ourselves in so many ways, it literally makes us want to sing! So now I pose the question back to you : do you love them? Only you know if they make you feel the ways in which I have described above, particularly with respect to good feelings and and the gravitational desire to gladly, passionately and mutually give of yourselves to one another. May you love deeply and be loved deeply in return all the days of your life. -A man who is blessed to know love deeply.

LOVE IS NOT A FEELING. LOVE IS A DAILY CHOICE. Why is it so rare for an individual to understand what love is? These questions and the attempts at their answers make me feel so awful because I know how much devastation this flawed perspective and definition can bring to a persons life. So many deaths have been caused by people misunderstanding what love is. So many deaths could be prevented by simply having better education on love. So much value has been wasted, all because people refuse to humble themselves long enough to grasp what love truly is. LOVE IS NOT A FEELING. LOVE IS A DAILY CHOICE. Everyone seems to think that love is a feeling, just because it can be used in that context. Someone says that they love going bike riding, or they love driving, or they love hanging out with friends, then they associate love with a feeling. It is true, there can be plenty of emotions that accompany love, the emotions range from blissful when cuddling to pure rage when someone they love is in critical trouble. These emotions and strong feelings are not the indication of whether love is real, the thoughts and actions the individual chooses indicate whether the love is real. When you're a parent you can’t believe that love is based on feeling and still be a good parent. Your children are DEFINITELY going to make you feel like strangling them. They are not going to be producing that lovey-dovey feeling in your heart 24/7. Neither will anyone on this earth EVER be capable of giving you those feelings for long periods of time. It’s just not ever going to happen, and anyone who says otherwise is either selling something or trying to make themselves feel better about their own wasted lives. LOVE IS NOT A FEELING. LOVE IS A DAILY CHOICE. Learn to avoid so much of life’s pain right now by grasping those capitalized words in the bold text. Love is not a feeling, love is a daily choice. Your emotion will follow your action regardless, that’s why you need to be the one to control love, don’t let your understanding of love control you. So many people in today’s society are mesmerized by the Hollywood fake idea of love. It’s infected so many places, so many institutions, even all across the academic world this is such a flagrant issue. We have this fear of being rejected and abandoned, yet we won’t stay committed to others unless we are getting those ‘lovey-dovey feelings’ at a guaranteed frequency? Come on, let's think a little harder here, it doesn’t take a genius to flip the roles and find out that you’re asking for something you’re not willing to give yourself. No. It’s not anyone else's responsibility to make you feel good. Regardless, you shouldn’t even concern yourself with anyone else’s responsibilities but your own. In a relationship, seek to love without keeping a record, seek to love without expecting anything in return, seek to love out of genuine love! LOVE IS NOT A FEELING. LOVE IS A DAILY CHOICE. THE END.

Hmmm…you know, my answer to this question has changed as many times as I’ve thought about it and probably more. When I was a teenager, I would have probably said something like “when you think about the person almost non-stop and just the thought of them makes you smile and you can see the 2 of your together forever.” I would’ve given you the typical juvenile answer but, of course, I would have thought it was prolific, haha. In my 20’s, after a couple disappointing long term relationships and a few short term dating fizzles, I probably would have said you know you’re in love when you don’t worry whether or not they’re going to take care of their shit!” Haha, yeah, I was very frustrated and I hadn’t yet realized that I was the common denominator in all the situations. Mmmhmm. Now that I’m in my 30’s, I think that love is a feeling that isn’t complete by itself. What I mean is that love can’t exist in a vacuum. It needs compassion and understanding and encouragement and constant reassurance and, above all, it needs faith. As a species, I think we mistakenly think that love- romantic love, that is - is supposed to be all hearts and butterflies and rainbows and we forget that 2 people are usually attracted to each other because they are the mirror image of each other; we gravitate to those who are strong where we are not and vice versa. And it’s a good method, for sure, narcissistic as it may be, haha - the trouble comes when we find a point that we both think is our strong point, and we don’t know how to agree to disagree. My boyfriend and I are both Alpha; both have been the “aggressor” in our previous relationships and when we first got together, anytime we got to one of those points where we both thought we knew we were right, you know, one of our “strong” points, it was Clash of the Titans version 4.0. I’m no shrinking violet and my boyfriend had never been with someone like me. It took us a while to make our adjustments, but it was quite the spectacle for my neighbors, I’m sure, haha. So, how do I know I’m in love? Because I still want to be here tomorrow. :) K

Last night me and my husband went out for dinner with one of our couple friends. He while having dinner:“I am not going to gym these days”. They asked him “Why?”. And he laughed and told them “There is no pretty girl coming in my gym these days so i don’t find any inspiration to go.” Well I didn’t say anything but I felt bad. And I was thinking that he doesn’t love me now. Then in the morning it was usual routine and I was busy with some household works. He: “Divya, can you come” Me: “What happened?”. He: “Have you seen my black jeans.” Me (Shouting): “Is this all my responsibility? Can’t you even take care of your own stuff. I have got so much to do and instead of helping me, you want me to find your jeans. Seriously this is too much!” He didn’t utter a single word. Still i searched and handed over that jeans to him. He smiled and hugged me with emotional eyes & pinched my cheeks. And said: “Thank you janu”. Me: “Take it now and from next time please do take care of at least your own things.” We both went to office. In evening after we returned. He (Smiling with naughty expressions): “See, I have ordered these grocery items for you.” Me (feeling good): “Okay thanks, but why you are saying that you have ordered for me. This is for both of us not just for me and anyway it’s very easy to order anything online. One day you do my tasks and then you will know how difficult it is to manage everything.” He laughed and hugged me and said: “Yes, you are right janu” At that moment I not only knew that I am in love with him but i also knew that he was in love with me too.  Answering this question. You know you are in love with someone when you fall in love with them everyday over and over again despite their flaws. ❤️ Thanks for reading. 💞 Check out my stories on Instagram: @divyasharmagoyal

Love feels different for everyone, but it tends to display a few common patterns. One could also argue that love has phases to not confuse infatuation with true, genuine care. Nonetheless, I’ve known my partner for five years, and we’ve been intimately, emotionally, and spiritually committed to one another for four years. Phase 1: A chemical reaction Photo by Ryan Graybill on Unsplash  I open the door and a wave of sounds and scents crash into my face. Music is blaring from a stereo system I can’t see yet, and the sweat and yeast invade my olfactory as if it were attempting to take over an enemy’s territory. I step inside and close the door behind me. As I look for a familiar face a woman walks past and smiles at me. A male raises a glass to me from across the room to say hello and welcome–he must be the host of this party? I walk further inside and find a dining room table surrounded by at least fifteen people. A woman at one hand tosses a plastic ping pong ball across the table. Her arms shoot up above her head. She cheers. The crowd erupts in elation. I scan the crowd to try and find my friend who invited me to the part, but he’s nowhere to be found yet. Walking through the main living area and down a hallway, I start poking my head into rooms to see if I can find him. The fourth door had promise. I nudged it open and heard voices. I poked my head inside and made myself known, “Hello?” “Whatsup?” I step inside and see my friend, Zack, sitting on a bed. Four other people at around the room, either on the floor or in a chair. And that’s when I saw her. Her hair blonde. Her eyes green. A toned body only a committed athlete would wield. A glass of clear liquid in her hand. Nails short but clean. My palms went a little clammy. My breathing shortened. I felt a rush “Chris? You in there, bud?” Zack had been talking to me, but I stopped listening the moment I saw her. As he introduced everyone, Zack pointed at each person. I shook their hands, but I couldn’t stop glancing back over at her. It was nothing profound, but the moment I saw my current partner, I felt a desire, craving, need to get to know her. I saw her appearance, and it attracted me to her. I then heard her voice, and I had to keep her talking. Eventually, we went on a few dates, and I was sold. We had to be together, but not unless she agreed with me. Phase 2: What’s trust got to do with it? Photo by ANDRIK LANGFIELD PETRIDES on Unsplash  “We agreed to be open.” “I am being open.” “No you’re not.” “I slept with him. What more do you need to know?” For the first 8 months of our relationship, we agreed to be open. This meant multiple partners, open communication, and the freedom to explore ourselves. It was a fun eight months, but it ended with a heated argument about how much information would be shared and how we began to feel about one another. At the time, I felt crazy. I thought I was the only one growing to love her, but she felt the same way. A funny thing happens when we begin to care for someone. We become vulnerable. We bare our softer selves, the secrets and the insecurities. We begin to trust our life to someone else. Share it with them. Expect them to be there for us. Unfortunately, my partner and I both felt betrayed, and here is why: Our open relationship at a certain point began to betray our core beliefs and values. Sure, we agreed to be open. We both were collegiate athletes holding up 3.8 GPAs or higher respectively (she’s smarter than me). We didn’t think we had time to “worry” about a “real” relationship, so we focused on having fun. The opposite happened. The openness evolved, and it became a friendship. That friendship, through intimacy, understanding, and compassion turned into trust. If her and I were to go to the next level in our relationship, we had to make a commitment to one another, monogamy. This isn’t to say everyone has to be monogamous, but for her and I, it’s a core value and belief. Until we made that shift, we weren’t going to be together. Sadly enough, the decision to be monogamous took 12 months of not talking to one another. We separated. I graduated from college. She had one more year. I got a job, and she studied and played her chosen sport. Phase 3: Commitment, loyalty, and growth Photo by Pablo Heimplatz on Unsplash  I met a few friends at a restaurant downtown on a Friday night. We decided to celebrate a friend’s promotion, another friend’s birthday, and a third friend’s pregnancy all at the same time. We ordered a few drinks. We ate. We had a good time all around. As we left the restaurant, Mike suggested we go give a new bar a try. It was down the street within walking distance. We all agreed, so we went. We got a table, got seated, and then looked around for a waiter/waitress. This bar apparently did have them. We had to order our own drinks at the bar. I volunteered to get the first round. As I walked up to the bar I heard a familiar laugh. Then I heard a familiar voice. I leaned onto the bar top and looked to my left. There she stood with a few friends, enjoying a drink and conversation. I never thought I’d see the woman I started to love ever again. We separated on a pretty clear agreement: No talking. No stalking. No thinking. I’d done my best for the last 12 months, but it was pretty tough. She made me tick. She gave me butterflies. I wanted to be the best for her. I wanted to help her achieve her dreams. The bartender got my order. I waited, trying to ignore her down the bar. Then I felt a tap on the shoulder. As I looked, I smiled. I knew it was her. “Chris, what’re you doing here?” I pointed over my shoulder, “Here with a few friends. Celebrating.” She stared into my eyes. I stared back. The bartender set the five drinks on the car top. I could feel the bass of the music in my fingers, and my heart beating out of my chest. The same feeling I had the night I met her overwhelmed me. “That’ll be–” She kissed me. Whatever the bartender had been saying disappeared into the ether as my lips pressed against hers. She pulled away. “Sorry. I’m–I don’t know.” “I thought we were over?” I asked. She grinned at me. I kissed her back. For the last four years, my partner and I have been living our values and beliefs together. We’re building loyalty, and we support one another no matter the cost. It’s a mutual agreement on what we believe love should be and how it should be lived. We’re building our lives… together. So how do you know if you’re in love? Do you feel attracted to that person? Do you trust that person? Are you loyal to you and that person’s definition of love? These are simple questions that require time, energy, and honesty with self and someone else (or more people, if you live that way). How you feel, experience, and define love will determine if you are in love or not. It’s simply a matter of listening to yourself, inquiring if the other person feels the same way you do, and living life together.

You don’t for the first year. The other person super turns you on and you want to breed with them. Hopefully your thinking brain sees the danger of the instinct, and purchases safe sex gear/birth control to use. Once this 1–2 year long lust state evaporates, you will see if you actually had LOVE. Then you will STILL want to stay with this person because they get you, you get them, and you have alot in common, especially in key points of how to live your lives. It’s useful to get a jump start on that last bit by knowing the person quite well before you ever jump in the sack together. A few months doesn’t really cut it. I’ve never been that patient; I only married my ‘soulmate’ because I knew her through highschool and we stayed friends through our 20’s’ when I was making mistakes on a bunch of other inappropriate chix. You’ll know they were wrong for you when the relationship breaks up somewhere around 14–20 months. It’s an error to stay just by stubbornness.

Falling in love is one of the most exciting, happy and scariest things that could ever happen to you. It's hard to remember how you lived without that person. Of course, you were alive before you met this person, but you didn't start “living” until the two of you met. For everyone, love is different. Even the definition of love is extremely personal, but I say for certain that anyone who's felt it agrees it's the best feeling ever. The best part of your day That person is always the highlight of your day. If you love someone, you never get tired of him. No matter how amazing your day is being, your special person will make it better. Your love is always the first person you think about when you wake up and the last person you think about before you go to sleep. It is the first person you want to tell when something good happens. If something bad happens, this is the person you look at for support. Love is selfless. You are the most important person in your world until you met him. When you are in love, his needs become much more important than your own, definitely first! That is just how love is. Your needs always seem trivial in comparison to your significant other's needs. When you're in love with someone, you do whatever you can to make the person happy. True love knows no limits. You are never afraid to express your feelings in public When you're truly in love, you want everyone to know. You are not bashful about your feelings by any means. You love the imperfections Your love is the most beautiful person, and of course, he does have some imperfections. But, to you, they're not imperfections. They're unique qualities and everything you love. Love is the ability to know and accept the other person's faults. It's difficult to imagine a future without that person in it. This is the reason you will plan long-term about everything that matters because all you want is a life with this person. Being in love makes you feel secure, confident and safe. When you are in Love you are not afraid of commitments. You experience a terrible pain if things may end. You definaly know you are in love. "There are plenty of ways to die, but only love can kill and keep you alive to feel it." — Leo Christopher

Love can be many things but to me, love is selflessness. This quality is very unique and only the closest people can love us selflessly,for example,our parents. I think you don't need any kind of explanation to justify this. They simply put us fisrt in everything. We are thier first preference. Their love is unconditional and very real. This need not be parents all the time, in some cases even our siblings, friends and relatives (rarely) can love us selflessly. Only when you are in love, you will be able to put their happiness before yours, their success becomes your pride, their problems become yours,their happiness becomes yours, their family becomes yours ,and so on. Selflessness is one of the things that show that your in love with someone so when you realize that you are selfless with someone that is when you are in love! Edit: Let me share a story about a girl. There was an athletic tournament in her school. Everyone was having a good time watching their friends playing, running ,and so on. She was eagerly waiting for the running race that was because her crush is participating in that. Finally,the race has started he was ready at the starting point. When he heard the sound he started running but her eyes were only on him. Everyone started shouting the names of their friends and encouraged them.She could not shout but her heart shouted his name and prayed for him to win.He was running so fast that all others were a few steps behind, on seeing this she stood up in her place and clapped so hard that her hands turned red. When he passed the finishing line her face was overwhelmed with so much of happiness and pride but she could not share this with anyone.He was jumping and hugging his friends and here she stood behind everyone not moving her eyes away from him , smiling like a idiot His victory was her pride,that is how she realized that she was in LOVE!

We started out just a school mates. And when my relationship of 3 years ended badly I began on a long path of self destructiveness. Drugs, alcohol, sex, unsafe behaviors to forget the pain I was in. Eventually we crossed paths in the summer and he was looking for something casual. At the time I didn't have the capacity for anything more than casual. So I agreed. No strings attached, just booty calls. So whenever we got the urge he'd come pick me up, often in the early morning hours. 1 am, 2am. We'd do our thing and I'd go directly home. No long stays, no meaningful talks. Just sex. Except there came a time when eventually he stopped taking me home right after. We'd watch a movie together. Or go out somewhere. Even play board games. I'd stay the night in his bed and sometimes he'd even cuddle me. Which in all honesty made me cringe, but he was a nice guy and just because I was incapable of romantic feelings didn't mean I had to be rude to him. It wasn't one big moment that I fell in love with him. It was all the small things he did for me. Introduced me to his family, who welcomed me with open arms.Was there for me, even if I never opened up to him about the shit I went through. Just understood that I was a little fucked up and didn't judge or pressure me.The way he'd sometimes put his hand on my thigh when he drove us places.The way he wasn't afraid to sing horribly in front of me. The smile he'd flash at me whenever he caught me staring at him. Even the way he was confident with his body. The first time he urinated in front of me he just did it. No shyness, no apology, no making me stop what I'm doing. And something about that kind of confidence was attractive. One night I found myself holding his hand and I looked our entwined fingers and I realized that I loved the feel of his calluses on my soft painters hands. I loved the feeling of his rough stubble on my lips. I loved that he made me feel something deep inside of me. A part once so abused I thought it was dead, and somehow he breathed life back into it. That's when realized I had fallen in love.

LOVE is an amazing feeling. I recently had an experience which convinced me to believe that I’d fallen in love with her. It was Uttarayan yesterday. For those of you who don’t know, in Ahmedabad, this festival is celebrated with enthusiasm that literally reaches the sky. After a long day of flying kites and enjoying delicacies, the sun had finally set. I was sitting on the water tank on the roof of my building. Music was playing - the genre and volume was good enough for me to get the “feels”. Following the pitch darkness that appeared in the sky, sky lanterns started appearing, accompanied by occasional fire works. Within few minutes, the sky was filled with lanterns - everywhere I could see dots of fire in the sky - giving it an ethereal beauty, for it was the first time I had seen the sky itself celebrating a festival. And in the moments that I was still trying to digest the surreal beauty of my surroundings, the thought of her appeared, from no where, in my mind. And the following few minutes I did nothing but mesmerized over how even the mere thought of her could make something that was already ethereal, more beautiful. And in that moment, I guess, I realized I had fallen in love with her. . The whole point of narrating this incident was to highlight how I think you know you love someone - when, at the least expected of times, their thought fills your heart and mind, following which you cannot help thinking anything but them - that’s when you know you are in love.

When no matter how much pain, trouble, tears and sleepless nights they have put you through and so many of the conversations of “please forgive me”s and “I'm so sorry”s and trying to find a compromise to your fight and you forgive them each time because you are not perfect and you've made them go through the same emotions and still forgive and support them 100% because not only do you have those bad days with them, you also have good days, amazing days. Days where you laugh, days where you cuddle, days where no one can stop you from being happy with your partner, days where you promise you'll always be with them through the best and through the worst. The test comes when you're there on those painful, troubling, sleepless nights and you know you love them because when everything told you to leave you stayed because for some reason you believe this person is worth growing with through sickness, through health, through the bad days and the good, you have chosen to stay. That is when you truly know you love them with all of your self.

There's a difference between when you are in love and when you feel when you are in love. This is when you feel that you are in love.When you wake up, the first thought is of her. The first thing you do after waking up is checking your phone for a message or call from her that you missed by any chance. You change yourself so that she may like you and adopt several things she likes even if you have to leave some of your most loved routines. Changing or avoiding your own opinion just to agree to her, so that she may not be upset with you. You'll want to talk to her everytime, every single minute of the day and at the end of the day, you may end up fighting because she doesn't give you enough time. This is when you are in loveLove is, when you wake up daily and think about how you'll spend the whole day to make it better for both of you. Dress the way you want to, not to impress anybody. When you can share your own opinions, and respect her opinions also. You'll do the things you love to do because you know that she'll always support you. You'll be yourself, there will be no fake layer, irrespective of the fact that you are so hard to handle as a person. And at last, even if you don't talk for the whole day, you send a Good Night text to her daily and won't sleep until she replies back. Love is a beautiful feeling. It is not limited to a guy or a girl, a married couple or some high school sweethearts. Love is present everywhere between every two persons who care about each other and accept each other for what they actually are. Thank you for reading.

Thought I’d share this lil movie scene in an attempt to make the whole discourse on love a little more LIGHT-HEARTED (before I then continue to go on with my own overly clichéd notion of love but shhh). Also if someone could pls shout out the name of this movie that would be greatly appreciated because I’m in need of another rom com as wholesome as the Before trilogy and a little less humiliating than He’s Just Not That into You because I cannot STAND to watch it for the 968th time. I BEG. Clichés pending: Most of the time it’s only really in heartbreak that you realise you are/were in love, or at least what you thought was love anyway. It’s the point at which they’re no longer in your life physically but you can still feel their presence. Whether you’re walking down the street, listening to a song, drinking your favourite milkshake, they’re still there. You see it wasn’t just the street, a song, or your milkshake. It was our street, our song and our favourite milkshake. Everything literally becomes tainted by them: movies and songs on into whole spaces, cities and experiences, emotions and it’s like you’re walking over their footprints constantly everywhere you go (both physically and mentally). Whenever you make a judgement about something it’s not really you making that judgment anymore, it’s like they’re whispering in your ear but not saying anything because you already know what they’d say, it would be the exact same thing as you. Their voice is essentially your voice. Being in love is an alignment. It’s like two parallel lines that never touch but instead fill the space between them. They’re running along at the exact same speed but never touch because they simply cannot, and that is the sadness of it all. But who knows, it’s all a mystery. You’re probably in love with someone in a completely different way than they are in love with you. So just don’t push them off into the sea, because I guarantee you they’ll find another fish in the meantime.

You sat beside me and told me how you could never go back to where you came from, how you were cursed to roam distant lands in search of home. I promised in my halting, joking, yearning way that I’d come be your family wherever you are. It was all I could give. It was all you would take. A year ago I realized I was homeless. A month ago you realized you’d found yours. It isn’t with me and I should have seen it coming, but — what do I do now with all this space I’d saved beside me for you?  You were once the hero in all of my daydreams, high on an improbable white horse and my most trusted brother-in-arms. It took all of your cruelty to disabuse me of my silly notions; I still wonder if it ever exhausted you, playing the villain to an unwitting victim. At night I drifted into uneasy sleep only to find you walking into my nightmares and ask me with your empty, haunted eyes if I’d ever been devastated. I woke up to find you’d sent word for help. I went charging into your wreckage and burned with you. I came out with my candy-coating melted off and my soul stirred into perpetual flames. You never came out at all.  I almost regret never deifying you. You’d have made a wonderful god, high up on your golden pedestal, smiling benevolently at your misguided worshipers. You sit beside me instead, and your smiles are conspiratorial, and your pedestal is imaginary at most and gilded at best. I wouldn’t have it any other way. I wound your pride every chance I get and you tear down every semblance of patience I’ve ever managed to construct. We fight when everyone’s watching and laugh when we’re alone. We both know this is all we’ll ever have. I wonder if you ever wanted more. I wonder if I ever wanted more.  I don’t know if I fell in love, or just loved as one does. All I know is that there are names etched into my heart, for better or for worse, that’ll forever haunt me. It is what came of it that mattered. It is what I make of it that matters.

1. "This one's special"When you're in love, you begin to think yourbeloved is unique. The belief is coupled withan inability to feel romantic passion foranyone else. Fisher and her colleaguesbelieve this single-mindedness results fromelevated levels of central dopamine — achemical involved in attention and focus — inyour brain.2. "She's perfect"People who are truly in love tend to focus onthe positive qualities of their beloved, whileoverlooking his or her negative traits. Theyalso focus on trivial events and objects thatremind them of their loved one, day-dreamingabout these precious little moments andmementos. This focused attention is alsothought to result from elevated levels ofcentral dopamine, as well as a spike incentral norepinephrine, a chemical associatedwith increased memory in the presence of newstimuli. [ 5 Surprising Animal Love Stories ]3. "I'm a wreck!"As is well known, falling in love often leads toemotional and physiological instability. Youbounce between exhilaration, euphoria,increased energy, sleeplessness, loss ofappetite, trembling, a racing heart andaccelerated breathing, as well as anxiety,panic and feelings of despair when yourrelationship suffers even the smallestsetback. These mood swings parallel thebehavior of drug addicts. And indeed, whenin-love people are shown pictures of theirloved ones, it fires up the same regions of thebrain that activate when a drug addict takesa hit. Being in love, researchers say, is a formof addiction.4. "Overcoming the challenge made us closer"Going through some sort of adversity withanother person tends to intensify romanticattraction. Central dopamine may beresponsible for this reaction, too, becauseresearch shows that when a reward isdelayed, dopamine-producing neurons in themid-brain region become more productive.5. "I'm obsessed with him"People who are in love report that theyspend, on average, more than 85 percent oftheir waking hours musing over their "loveobject." Intrusive thinking, as this form ofobsessive behavior is called, may result fromdecreased levels of central serotonin in thebrain, a condition that has been associatedwith obsessive behavior previously.(Obsessive-compulsive disorder is treatedwith serotonin-reuptake inhibitors.)6. "I wish we could be together all the time"People in love regularly exhibit signs ofemotional dependency on their relationship ,including possessiveness, jealousy, fear ofrejection, and separation anxiety.7. "I hope we stay together forever"They also long for emotional union with theirbeloved, seeking out ways to get closer andday-dreaming about their future together.8. "I'd do anything for her"People who are in love generally feel apowerful sense of empathy toward theirbeloved, feeling the other person's pain astheir own and being willing to sacri?ceanything for the other person.9. "Would he like this outfit?"Falling in love is marked by a tendency toreorder your daily priorities and/or changeyour clothing, mannerisms, habits or valuesin order for them to better align with those ofyour beloved.10. "Can we be exclusive?"Those who are deeply in love typicallyexperience sexual desire for their beloved, butthere are strong emotional strings attached:The longing for sex is coupled withpossessiveness, a desire for sexualexclusivity, and extreme jealousy when thepartner is suspected of infidelity. Thispossessiveness is thought to have evolved sothat an in-love person will compel his or herpartner to spurn other suitors, therebyinsuring that the couple's courtship is notinterrupted until conception has occurred. [5Strange Courting Rituals from Around theWorld]11. "It's not about sex"While the desire for sexual union is importantto people in love, the craving for emotionalunion takes precedence.  A study found that64 percent of people in love (the samepercentage for both sexes) disagreed with thestatement, “Sex is the most important part ofmy relationship with [my partner]."12. "I feel out of control"Fisher and her colleagues found thatindividuals who report being "in love"commonly say their passion is involuntaryand uncontrollable.13. "The spark is gone"Unfortunately, being in love usually doesn'tlast forever. It's an impermanent state thateither evolves into a long-term, codependentrelationship that psychologists call"attachment," or it dissipates, and therelationship dissolves. If there are physical orsocial barriers inhibiting partners from seeingone another regularly — for example, if therelationship is long-distance — then the "inlove" phase generally lasts longer than itwould otherwise.
